claim: If wet-weather tires had been prohibited from 2000 to 2005, the number of drivers born before 1985 who completed more than 50 laps would have been lower.
extra_info: born before 1985 refers to year(dob)<1985; in 2000 to 2005 refers to year between 2000 and 2005; percentage = Divide(COUNT(driverId where year (dob) <1985 and laps >50),COUNT(DriverID where year between 2000 and 2005) *100;
reasoning: This is a counterfactual claim ('If wet-weather tires had been prohibited...'). It describes a hypothetical scenario that never occurred. The database only records what actually happened, not what would have happened under imagined rule changes. Counterfactual claims cannot be verified from a database and must be classified as NOT ENOUGH INFO.

content.text:
This claim describes a hypothetical "what if" scenario: "If wet-weather tires had been prohibited from 2000 to 2005..." This is a counterfactual claim about what would have happened under imaginary conditions that never occurred.

The database records what actually happened in Formula 1 races. It cannot tell us what would have happened if wet-weather tires had been prohibited. There is no way to verify or refute this hypothetical scenario from historical data alone.
